Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Fluorescence Lifetime Imaging Microscope System for Research, Undergraduate Research and Training, and Curricular Reform
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) programs. Professor Luke Haverhals from Bradley University and colleague Edward Remsen have acquired a fluorescence lifetime imaging microscope. Fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM) is a powerful technique that gives information about the location and the environment of a chemical (a fluorophore) that emits light after absorbing energy. The information obtained from initial samples provides feedback for the development of subsequent attempts, all with the goal of generating tough, functional materials made primarily from biomass while using minimal amounts of recyclable, low volatility organic compounds. The synthesized materials are low cost, sustainable composites that leverage the complex structures created by Nature. Technologies that may be improved by this instrument acquisition include: low carbon building materials as well as composites for automotive, aerospace, and medical applications. The new materials may also be used in water remediation, solar and electrochemical energy conversion and storage, and sensors. The research is conducted in collaboration with scientists at Knox College, Western Illinois University, and the US Department of Agriculture National Center for Agricultural Utilization Research (USDA NCAUR). The acquisition is used to train the next generation of scientists. In particular, experience in advanced microscopy techniques benefits master's level and undergraduate students as they prepare for advanced degree programs and industry.

The newly acquired Fluorescence Lifetime Imaging Microscope (FLIM) enhances research and education at Bradley University. The instrument facilitates the characterization of sustainable processing and manufacturing of composites, the exploration of natural fiber welding to create functional biocomposites, and the analyses of illicit substances. The instrumentation is used for high throughput screening of peptides, affibodies, and antibodies on surfaces; localizing cellular intersection; and studying transport within micro and mesoporous metal oxide porous films.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant has supported a fluorescence lifetime imaging (FLIM) microscope system that is helping researchers to develop functional composites and nanomaterials. For example, the FLIM system obtained has helped researchers better understand and develop new ways to manufacture and recycle abundant natural fibers into new high performance natural composite fabrics.  Studying the underlying structures of natural fibers before and after processing is helpful to develop new manufacturing that recycles natural fibers even while giving these materials new properties they did not have before. This is a leading potential solution to disrupt humanity's overdependence on fossil resource-based synthetic plastics in the global textile industry by displacing plastics with renewable performance textiles - even when made from "waste" cotton fibers. (See Figures 1 & 2.) 

In addition, the FLIM instrument has enabled the study of cell cultures and provided enhanced discrimination of novel cell lines.  (See Figure 3.) The microscope funded by this MRI grant has been useful to develop analytical techniques that investigate the surface chemistries of nano-abrasives. Understanding surface interactions is a key requirement for the development of processing methods used in the manufacture next generation microelectronics. 

The FLIM also enabled the study of interactions between bacterial cells and cationic amphiphilic ternary PEGylated polymers (See Figure 4.). These polymeric systems belong to a class of materials which exhibit antibacterial activities towards different strains of bacteria. The antibacterial effect of these materials is mainly based on biocidal action where the cationic (positively charged) polymers are adsorbed on the surface of the negatively charged bacterial cell wall. The hydrophobic domains of the polymers and bacterial cells interact resulting in complete disruption of the cell wall and in the subsequent death of the bacterial cells.

It is also notable that this grant has contributed significantly to training the next generation of scientists as they are mentored while taking on active roles in innovative and self-directed research.  In particular, experience in advanced microscopy techniques has benefited master's level and undergraduate students as they prepare for advanced degree programs and for technical jobs in industry.
